title: Unpopular Opinion --> You can't cross compare AD vs AP resistances, so stop it already.
body:
Let me explain this, for those of you who are a bit slow in the head.

You simply cannot compare these two items to one another:

|{{item:3156}} | and |{{item:3157}}|

To begin, one of these items is designed to help against Magic Damage, and the other is designed to aid against Physical Damage.

There are MANY options in the game for both armor and magic resist. For example we have items such as these:

|{{item:3001}} | {{item:3194}} | {{item:3065}} | {{item:3190}} | {{item:3231}} | {{item:3102}} | {{item:3512}} |  and obviously | {{item:3163}}|

To put this into perspective, there are two Magic Resist items for Ability Power, and two for Attack Damage.

Magic Damage: |{{item:3001}}| {{item:3102}}|

Physical Damage: |{{item:3156}}| {{item:3139}}|

In this regard, both damage dealers are on near equal footing when it comes to available defenses for magic resistance. If you are still worried about it, there's still a few other items available for both sides that you could be building from the list without having to worry about building Attack Damage that you do not want or need.

Now, let's look at the flip side. Here are some items which are designed with armor:

|{{item:3025}} | {{item:3190}} |{{item:3056}} |{{item:3143}} |{{item:3800}} |{{item:3068}} |{{item:3075}} |{{item:3306}} | {{item:3512}} | {{item:3026}}| and once more, obviously: |{{item:3157}} |

For Magic Damage champions, this item is available: |{{item:3157}} |

For Physical Damage champions, there is: |{{item:3026}}|

If either side is still worried about it, there are a decent list of Armor items which are neutral and can be shared between both Attack Damage and Magical Damage champions.

So, the next time you want to complain about (insert bias'd champion pool here) vs (insert bias'd champion pool here), take a second to remember that game balance goes far beyond the short sighted reasoning and twisted logic you are using to support your desires.

Both Magic Damage champions and Physical Damage champions have two items for Magic Resist, and also one item for Armor. 

They are equal.

Hexdrinker virtually ensures an AD champion cannot be bursted by a mage in a 1v1, making him near unkillable, without sacrificing what his build needs (raw ad). Seekers only provides some armor (can easily still be killed through it) and doesn't provide what a mage wants early (Mana and CDR). 

Likewise, removing cc at will is much better than absorbing the first spell to hit you. Obviously choice >>>> automatic. 

And at the end of the day - you can't compare armor to MR because the damage is different - I agree. A single MR item is often enough for a tank against magic damage dealers, while 4-5 armor items still isn't enough against AD. Yet that maw gives more MR than zhonya's gives armor. So yes, they're not comparable. Armor is weaker than MR, and yet the ad itemization option gives more defense, the better build path (i.e. considerably better partial item), and more survivability in the passive. 

The only reason they can't be compared is because it's so uneven...

While I'm not going to argue with your logic (a shield helping more than a few armors), I think much of the problem is the logic of players isn't keeping up with the changes in the game. Consider the following, a long time ago games were slow and generally required wise use of your gold and timing in order be as efficient as possible and win trades, lanes, and games against the other team. This led people to be very picky about the type of items they were building -- wasting anything meant that you might not actually be able to win against your enemy because every stat you gained mattered a lot.

Fast forward a ways, most players can agree that games are fast and damage is insanely high. Gold efficiency has lost most of the meaning that it used to have. League has transformed into a game about snowballing and almost completely removed the aspect of strategy and slow methodical gameplay. The problem with this is, the player base still thinks identical to the past, when things like how viable an item was mattered. This means that some items which might help them in certain situations, players aren't purchasing because they've been trained over several seasons that those items aren't viable.

It's not much different from a video that I saw Doublelift post, where he mentioned how long it took Starcraft Protoss players to find a solution to dealing with the Zerg. When you don't know the answer and it seems unfair, the most common reaction by players is to complain. The fact is however, there are a lot of options that none of the player base is trying because the meta in League has been shifting so fast and so often. The crowd of this game often doesn't help much either. Trying new things gets you flamed, and that in part is why a lot of players would rather complain than look for answers to the problem.
